articles.headline: Justice Dept., Criticizing Philadelphia Police, Finds Shootings by Officers Are Common
articles.snippet: A Justice Department report about the Philadelphia Police Department does not allege racial discrimination, but indicates that the city stands out when it comes to shootings by officers.
articles.abstract: A Justice Department report about the Philadelphia Police Department does not allege racial discrimination, but indicates that the city stands out when it comes to shootings by officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Roughly once a week, 390 times over the past eight years, Philadelphia police officers opened fire at a suspect. The shootings involved 454 officers, most of them on patrol. Almost always, the suspects were black. Often, the officers were, too.

articles.headline: Police Find No Evidence of Rape at University of Virginia Fraternity
articles.snippet: The announcement came four months after a now-discredited report in Rolling Stone magazine of a gang rape at a fraternity rocked the campus.
articles.abstract: The announcement came four months after a now-discredited report in Rolling Stone magazine of a gang rape at a fraternity rocked the campus.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — The police here said Monday that they had found “no substantive basis” to support a Rolling Stone magazine article depicting a horrific gang rape at a University of Virginia fraternity house and that a four-month review had identified serious discrepancies in the account by a woman identified as Jackie, who refused to cooperate with their investigation.
articles.byline: By Owen Robinson and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: U.S. Private Equity Firms Find a Chilly Reception in Australia
articles.snippet: Despite the challenges presented in Australia, American private equity giants are pushing ahead with investments there.
articles.abstract: Despite the challenges presented in Australia, American private equity giants are pushing ahead with investments there.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — When the financing arm of General Electric agreed last week to sell its consumer lending business in Australia and New Zealand to a consortium of investors that included the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the firm’s managing partner for Asia trumpeted the news.

articles.headline: Netanyahu Apologizes; White House Is Unmoved
articles.snippet: Despite an apology by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the White House remained furious about comments that appeared to close the door on a two-state solution to the Palestinian conflict.
articles.abstract: Despite an apology by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, the White House remained furious about comments that appeared to close the door on a two-state solution to the Palestinian conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel apologized on Monday for making what were widely condemned as racist comments last week in saying that Arab citizens were voting in “droves.”
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Deep Freeze on Great Lakes Halts Cargo Shipments
articles.snippet: Two harsh winters have burdened ship lines and businesses that depend on their cargo, including grain and iron ore.
articles.abstract: Two harsh winters have burdened ship lines and businesses that depend on their cargo, including grain and iron ore.
articles.lead_paragraph: THUNDER BAY, Ontario — The trip to pick up a load of iron ore powder in Conneaut, Ohio, was supposed to take four days by way of the Great Lakes.
articles.byline: By Ian Austen and Mary M. Chapman

articles.headline: Ted Cruz, an Ambitious Conservative With Sharp Elbows
articles.snippet: The Republican senator from Texas, a Tea Party favorite who declared himself a presidential candidate on Monday, became known as an ambitious upstart who rubbed even some fellow Republicans the wrong way.
articles.abstract: The Republican senator from Texas, a Tea Party favorite who declared himself a presidential candidate on Monday, became known as an ambitious upstart who rubbed even some fellow Republicans the wrong way.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Back in late 2000, Ted Cruz found himself with one of the hottest tickets in town.
articles.byline: By Ashley Parker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: No Need to Run in Hawaii: The Lava Is Coming, but Very Slowly
articles.snippet: Residents of the Hawaiian town of Pahoa have learned to adapt as a slow-moving lava flow menaces their community.
articles.abstract: Residents of the Hawaiian town of Pahoa have learned to adapt as a slow-moving lava flow menaces their community.
articles.lead_paragraph: PAHOA, Hawaii — If a disaster movie played out in slow motion, it might look a bit like the Puna District on the Big Island of Hawaii.

articles.headline: As Oil Prices Fall, Airfares Still Stay High
articles.snippet: Far from “hypercompetitive,” the airline industry nowadays is increasingly looking like an uncompetitive oligopoly.
articles.abstract: Far from “hypercompetitive,” the airline industry nowadays is increasingly looking like an uncompetitive oligopoly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just over two years ago, one of the nation’s airline trade organizations called the industry “hypercompetitive” and declared “airfare remains a bargain.” At the time, the Justice Department was weighing the competitive implications of a merger between American Airlines and US Airways, around two years after the merger of United and Continental.

articles.headline: Wynn Resorts Fight Over Board Seat Has Roots in Divorce Settlement
articles.snippet: Elaine Wynn, who received a stake in the casino owner Wynn Resorts in a divorce settlement, is campaigning to hold her board seat.
articles.abstract: Elaine Wynn, who received a stake in the casino owner Wynn Resorts in a divorce settlement, is campaigning to hold her board seat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Without a trace of bitterness, the billionaire Stephen A. Wynn once described his divorce from Elaine P. Wynn as the most expensive in American history. They evenly split his stake in the casino-resort company they co-founded and seemed to remain compatible leaders of some of the most profitable hotel-casinos in the world.

articles.headline: Facebook May Host News Sites’ Content
articles.snippet: The social media giant is said to be in talks with several news publishers, offering to deliver their content quickly, in exchange for a certain loss of control over their readership.
articles.abstract: The social media giant is said to be in talks with several news publishers, offering to deliver their content quickly, in exchange for a certain loss of control over their readership.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nothing attracts news organizations like Facebook. And nothing makes them more nervous.
articles.byline: By Ravi Somaiya, Mike Isaac and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Iran’s Hard-Liners Show Restraint on Nuclear Talks With U.S.
articles.snippet: Iran’s usually vocal clerics and military commanders are heeding the call of the country’s supreme leader, who has largely supported the negotiations.
articles.abstract: Iran’s usually vocal clerics and military commanders are heeding the call of the country’s supreme leader, who has largely supported the negotiations.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A coterie of Iran’s hard-line Shiite Muslim clerics and Revolutionary Guards commanders is usually vocal on the subject of the Iranian nuclear program, loudly proclaiming the country’s right to pursue its interests and angrily denouncing the United States.

articles.headline: As Silence Falls on Chicago Trading Pits, a Working-Class Portal Also Closes
articles.snippet: The pits where traders once bellowed out orders for wheat, corn and cattle contracts are scheduled to close this summer, eliminating dozens of jobs and, for many, a way of life.
articles.abstract: The pits where traders once bellowed out orders for wheat, corn and cattle contracts are scheduled to close this summer, eliminating dozens of jobs and, for many, a way of life.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The pits where generations of sweating traders in colorful jackets once bellowed out orders for wheat, corn and cattle contracts, using hand signals and sheer force of personality, are almost empty. The smattering of traders who hung around them on a recent day appeared listless, some glancing at tablet screens, others staring blankly into space.

articles.headline: U.S. to Delay Pullout of Troops From Afghanistan to Aid Strikes
articles.snippet: President Obama is keeping troops in Afghanistan partly to bolster counterterrorism efforts there, including the C.I.A.’s ability to conduct drone strikes, officials said.
articles.abstract: President Obama is keeping troops in Afghanistan partly to bolster counterterrorism efforts there, including the C.I.A.’s ability to conduct drone strikes, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s decision to maintain troop levels in Afghanistan through 2015 is partly designed to bolster American counterterrorism efforts in that country, including the Central Intelligence Agency’s ability to conduct secret drone strikes and other paramilitary operations from United States military bases, administration officials said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Police Shooting Victim in Georgia Tried to Follow ‘Sensible’ Path
articles.snippet: Long before two bullets from an officer’s gun tore through Anthony Hill’s chest, he had tattooed it with his grandfather’s advice: “Be sensible.” And he had done his best to heed that counsel.
articles.abstract: Long before two bullets from an officer’s gun tore through Anthony Hill’s chest, he had tattooed it with his grandfather’s advice: “Be sensible.” And he had done his best to heed that counsel.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONCKS CORNER, S.C. — Long before two bullets from a police officer’s handgun tore through Anthony Hill’s chest, he had tattooed it with the words of advice that his grandfather regularly imparted to him in this small Southern city: “Be sensible.”

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Caught Between Dueling Forces on Education: Teachers and Wealthy Donors
articles.snippet: The pressure Hillary Rodham Clinton faces shows the demands she will have to contend with on a number of divisive domestic issues that flared up during the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: The pressure Hillary Rodham Clinton faces shows the demands she will have to contend with on a number of divisive domestic issues that flared up during the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time she ran for president, Hillary Rodham Clinton did not have to take a position on the Common Core, Race to the Top or teacher evaluations in tenure decisions.

articles.headline: Radio and TV Martí, U.S. Broadcasters to Cuba, Emerge From Cold War Past Facing Uneasy Future
articles.snippet: The Martís are illegal on the island, and President Raúl Castro has made their shutdown a condition of normalizing relations with the United States.
articles.abstract: The Martís are illegal on the island, and President Raúl Castro has made their shutdown a condition of normalizing relations with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The rat-a-tat Cuban-inflected Spanish of the two Radio Martí hosts ricocheted back and forth during “Revoltillo,” a show laced with humor that airs classified ads posted in Cuba on a Craigslist-style website called Revolico.
